title: Cut out or incised lettering?
content:
I am rather embarrassed to ask the question since I always shun this type of lettering but my arm is being twisted. What ever happened to posting anonymously ?   
   
I am looking for a letter style that the copy appears to be cut out or incised out of a wood board, even better if it also has a western or cowboy feel, any suggestions?   
   
Thanks,   
gln
author: gln

comments.content:
Try entering "wood" in the MyFonts search.   
   
hhp
Gerald, if its only a couple of words I suggest you set the type in Photoshop and use layer styles to create the cutout feel. That way you can choose almost any font that works with the style

[http://www.baselinefonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125100644/http:/www.baselinefonts.com/)   
   
RODEO 58   
 ![rodeo.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125100644im_/http:/www.typophile.com/cgibin/board-post.pl?action=posting_upload_form&what=show&img=25898)  
   
WOODGRIT HEAVY   
 ![woodgrit_heavy.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125100644im_/http:/www.typophile.com/cgibin/board-post.pl?action=posting_upload_form&what=show&img=25899)  
   
TUSCAN CONDENSED   
 ![tuscan_condensed.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125100644im_/http:/www.typophile.com/cgibin/board-post.pl?action=posting_upload_form&what=show&img=25900)  
   
If you need something more CUTOUT, Max Kisman has a few fonts like that over at [http://www.HollandFonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125100644/http:/www.hollandfonts.com/)
Jim those are great fonts. Gerald if you need the style in Photoshop to give you the cut in effect I'll find it for you.

_Dan W,_   
   
I am still running Photoshop 5.5   
I'm not sure that version has a style for the cut in affect.   
  
   
_Jim R,_   
   
Thanks for the postings, they look very promising.   
   
_gln_

Gerald, here is the formula in case you have styles in Photoshop 5.5.   
Bevel/Emboss \> Pillow Smooth \> 390% \> Size 2 \> Soften 4   
Inner Glow \> 100% Opacity \> Solid Color (choose your own) \> Technique: Percise \> Source: Center   
Inner Shadow \> Multiply Black \> 75% \> Distance 7 \> Size 7   
   
This will give you a good starting point. When you make the effect put the type above your wood image and change the blending effects to Multiply
